newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU increases pressure for more say in Middle East.
newsitem.headline: EU increases pressure for more say in Middle East.

text.p: Israel's strenuous rebuff of French offers to join the Middle East peace process will not prevent the European Union from pressing for a greater say in the region, diplomats and officials said on Monday.

"We do not just want to be the money box for the Middle East," said Josep Coll I Carbo, a spokesman for the European Commission. "Our position is clear, we have the political will and mutual confidence to make a real contribution."

The Commission -- the EU's executive -- has been closely involved in diplomatic efforts by the 15-nation bloc for a Middle East role more in keeping with what it considers to be its significant financial contribution.
Diplomats say the EU will step up pressure for involvement next week when the bloc's foreign ministers gather for a regular meeting in Luxembourg.

Ireland -- which holds the current presidency of the EU -- is finalising proposals for ministers to consider appointing a special envoy to the region with a role similar to that enjoyed by EU representatives in Bosnia and Africa's Great Lakes region.
The last thing the EU wants is to appoint an envoy who would not be entertained by Israel, and that is a real fear given the reception accorded French President Jacques Chirac on Monday.
Chirac's weekend offer for France or Europe to mediate in the stalled peace process was brushed aside by Israeli officials and the press on Monday.

"I would be very careful before I would add more cooks to the broth," said Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. "I don't think at this time in such sensitive negotiations it would be wise to introduce another interlocutor."

Chirac -- who arrived in Jerusalem on Monday -- defended his weekend call for an EU peace role, saying: "I did not come here to teach people lessons...I am simply saying that we are available and we have valid reasons to be involved."
He added: "A certain balance of things may justify the presence of Europe and of France."
EU diplomats said on Monday that next week's Luxembourg meeting was not a question of whether to appoint an envoy, but rather who to appoint.
"There is some debate as to whether the envoy should be a political figure or a diplomatic figure," said one EU official. "The thinking at the moment is that it should be political."

Diplomats stressed that the EU was not looking actually to sit a representative at the same table as Israeli and Palestinian officials, but rather coordinate the disparate European interests in the region.

The EU has been the most prominent bankroller of development efforts in Palestinian-controlled areas of Gaza and the West Bank and, more significantly, is also discussing lucrative trade ties with Israel under the umbrella of its Mediterranean policy.

EU officials are reluctant to use the threat of cancelling Israel's participation as a lever into the peace process, but diplomats said one of the envoy's tasks "would be to remind all the parties of our considerable assistance".
The presence of Egyptian Foreign Minister Amr Moussa in Luxembourg will not help assuage Israeli feelings that the EU is biased towards the Palestinians in its Middle East policy.

Moussa will be in Luxembourg for a so-called "cooperation council" a regular meeting during which EU foreign ministers review relations with trading partners. Israel and the Middle East peace process will figure large in that review, diplomats said.
